list_definition.definition: a liquid that would supposedly make people able to go on living for ever, or a substance that would turn the cheaper metals into gold

list_ex_of_english: They tried by magic to find the elixir of life, believing that then there would be no more trouble.
Here, alongside the elixir of ozone and holiday remembrances, there exists an enticing picture of crime-free boulevards and peer-group sociability.
To a constituency like mine, development and growth is the elixir of life, but we have had so little of it.
The rural measure in particular is one that we hope will help to characterize some of the information networks that may have influenced prescription and consumption of elixir sulfanilamide.
The wonder cure is an easy bait with which to catch the gullible reporter, but peddling the elixir of life has a long history.
Before the "elixir" was put on the market, it was tested by the firm for flavor but not for its effect on human life.
In other words, does publicity in itself produce some wonderful spur to and elixir for enterprise?
They implicate magic, alchemy and various forms of nonscientific knowledge in the production of sources of eternal youth, and identify a public susceptibility to such elixirs.
